summary.para: Class representing the Acceleration / Tilt Sensor sensor from HiTechnic: http://www.hitechnic.com

remarks.para: A special thanks to the people at HiTechnic for providing me with the necessary technical information.
Also a special thanks to Ronny H. for providing me with qualified implementation details on the acceleration sensor before I had purchased my own copy.

summary.para: Change this value, to finetune the value of the acceleration sensor.
The current value, = 9.82/206.3, is the best fit for my own sensor.

remarks.para: The component used in the sensor is only guaranteed to be accurate to +/- 10%.

This class is a proxy for the MotorControl software which must be downloaded to, and running on the NXT brick.

remarks.para: It requires that MotorControl is downloaded to the NXT block and is running.

member.name: M:NKH.MindSqualls.MotorControl.MotorControlProxy.CONTROLLED_MOTORCMD(NKH.MindSqualls.NxtCommunicationProtocol,NKH.MindSqualls.MotorControl.MotorControlMotorPort,System.String,System.String,System.Char)

summary.para: Sends a command to the NXT brick to run CONTROLLED_MOTORCMD - to run the motor(s) with the given parameters.

remarks.para: From the MotorControl documentation:

This is the most important command. It contains a lot of parameters to tell the according motor(s) how and where to move. This is the actual reason MotorControl was developed. However, in certain situations, CLASSIC_MOTORCMD should be used instead (see below why). One of the reasons we have to decide in the high-level-client when to use CONTROLLED_MOTORCMD and when not is that in NXC, CPU-time is valuable, while on a computer we've got plenty!

member.param: The communication link to the NXT brick.
Power - 3 chars from "0" to "200". "0" to "100" = power 0 to 100; "101" to "200" = power -1 to -100.
Tacho limit - 6 chars from "0" to "999999". "0" means driving forever, no limit (better not use it, see also CLASSIC_MOTORCMD); everything else: drive to specific position.

Mode: 1 char, bitfield. Compose bits to integer (by OR or +), convert to char - Start with 0x00 (000); Set 0x01 (001) / add 1: Set for HoldBrake (keeps active brake on after end of movement); Set 0x02 (010) / add 2: Set to enable SpeedRegulation; Set 0x04 (100) / add 4: Set to enable SmoothStart.

member.name: M:NKH.MindSqualls.MotorControl.MotorControlProxy.RESET_ERROR_CORRECTION(NKH.MindSqualls.NxtCommunicationProtocol,NKH.MindSqualls.MotorControl.MotorControlMotorPort)

summary.para: Sends a command to the NXT brick to run RESET_ERROR_CORRECTION - to reset the NXT's internal error correction mechanism.

remarks.para: From the MotorControl documentation:

This command can be used to reset the NXT's internal error correction mechanism (i.e. reset the TachoCount property). The same thing can be achieved using the IO map commands (with the output module).

member.param: The communication link to the NXT brick.

member.name: M:NKH.MindSqualls.MotorControl.MotorControlProxy.ISMOTORREADY(NKH.MindSqualls.NxtCommunicationProtocol,NKH.MindSqualls.MotorControl.MotorControlMotorPort)

summary.para: Sends a command to the NXT block to run ISMOTORREADY - query if the motor is ready.

remarks.para: From the MotorControl documentation:

This command is used to determine the state of a single motor: Is it currently executing a command (i.e. moving) or is it ready to accept new commands? Bi-directional communication is used. We send a request and keep asking for the reply (i.e. we poll the computer's inbox). We have to make sure that for each request we make, we also retrieve the answer (to leave MotorControl in a clean state). Please note that we can (in theory) make multiple requests concerning different motors at the same time, as long as we keep polling the incoming mailbox and collect all replies.

member.param: The communication link to the NXT brick.

member.name: M:NKH.MindSqualls.MotorControl.MotorControlProxy.CLASSIC_MOTORCMD(NKH.MindSqualls.NxtCommunicationProtocol,NKH.MindSqualls.MotorControl.MotorControlMotorPort,System.String,System.String,System.Char)

summary.para: Sends a command to the NXT brick to run CLASSIC_MOTORCMD - to run the motor(s) with the given parameters.

remarks.para: From the MotorControl documentation:

This command is very similar to the classic SetOutputState: Sometimes we don't need any fance position control algorith, we just want to drive the motors. So this command is used when we have a TachoLimit of 0. Actually we don't have to invoke our NXC MotorControl program at all if we just want to drive without a TachoLimit. We could use SetOutputState, but this is a bit dangerous: It could interfere with a command that's already being executed by MotorControl. For this and some other design reasons, we pass the parameters on to MotorControl just as we do for controlled operations. Another situation when this command is applicable: Stopping in COAST mode, i.e. when you set a TachoLimit, but you want the motor to coast to a very soft stop. Then the NXC program doesn't have to do anything for us. In this case, this command just does a ResetErrorCorrection and a SetOutput for us in NXC.
Summary: When to use CLASSIC_MOTORCMD (instead of CONTROLLED_MOTORCMD)?

list.item: When you want your motor to coast (spin freely) after a TachoLimit has been reached (it will overshoot then).
When you want to change the power of a currently running motor, you can use this command to overwrite the power level at runtime (only works if the operation wasn't started with CONTROLLED_MOTORCMD).

member.param: The communication link to the NXT brick.
Power - 3 chars from "0" to "200". "0" to "100" = power 0 to 100; "101" to "200" = power -1 to -100.
Tacho limit - 6 chars from "0" to "999999". "0" means driving forever (no limit); everything else: drive to specific position.

summary.para: Polls the sensor, and fires the NXT-G like events if appropriate.
Abstract class representing a Active Sensor.

remarks.para: According to the LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT Hardware Developer Kit p. 7, sensors is divided into three types: active sensors (e.g. Robotics Invention Systems sensors), passive sensors (e.g. the NXT touch, light, and sound sensors), and digital sensors (e.g. the NXT ultrasonic sensor and the HiTechnic compass sensor). The three abstract classes NxtActiveSensor, NxtPassiveSensor, and NxtDigitalSensor reflect this.

summary.para: Abstract class representing the NXT communication protocol.

remarks.para: The communication protocol for the NXT brick is specified in the documents:

Lego Mindstorms NXT,
Bluetooth Developer Kit,
Appendix 1: LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT Communication protocol
- and:
Appendix 2: LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT Direct commands

- which can be downloaded at:
http://mindstorms.lego.com/overview/NXTreme.aspx

For NXT 2.0 specific informaton:
http://www.ni.com/pdf/manuals/372574c.pdf

A special thanks goes to Bram Fokke for his NXT# project:
http://nxtsharp.fokke.net/
Without his work, I doubt very much if my own work would have gotten off the ground. I have even st... ehem... borrowed a bit of his code here and there. However the major part of the code is my own.

summary.para: Use run/break instead of run/float in PWM.
Power control will be enabled on specified output.

remarks.para: Explantion of the values is found on p. 46 of the Executable File Specification document.

summary.para:
Reference: BDK, Appendix 2, p. 9.
Reference: BDK, Appendix 2, p. 11. (see MessageRead() function).
Abstract class representing a Digital sensor, i.e. a sensor using the I2C protocol.

remarks.para: The "Device Memory Arrangement" for a Digital sensor is specified at p. 10 of the document:

LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT,
Hardware Developer Kit

which can be downloaded at:
http://mindstorms.lego.com/overview/NXTreme.aspx
The Ultrasonic sensor protocol is specifed in appendix 7 of the HDK.
"Digital I/O Communication Methods" is also explained in the Executable File Specification document, p. 70-72.
.oOo.

According to the LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT Hardware Developer Kit p. 7, sensors is divided into three types: active sensors (e.g. Robotics Invention Systems sensors), passive sensors (e.g. the NXT touch, light, and sound sensors), and digital sensors (e.g. the NXT ultrasonic sensor and the HiTechnic compass sensor). The three abstract classes NxtActiveSensor, NxtPassiveSensor, and NxtDigitalSensor reflect this.

member.name: M:NKH.MindSqualls.NxtDigitalSensor.SendN(System.Byte[],System.Byte)

summary.para: Sends an I2C request to the Ultrasonic sensor, and receive the reply if applicable.

member.returns: The reply from the sensor, or a null-value

summary.para: Sends an I2C request to the Ultrasonic sensor, and receives the reply.

remarks.pare: Intended for the special case where a 1-byte reply is expexted.

summary.para: Delay-time (in milliseconds) from when a LsWrite() has been sent to a LsRead() is attempted.

remarks.para: Bluetooth connection: By waiting a few milliseconds, the chance of calling the I2C bus before it is ready is reduced. This reduces the times where an error-condition arises, and thereby increases the overall efficiency and throughput.
USB connection: Not used.

summary.para: Both the Ultrasonic sensor and the Compass plus Color sensors from HiTecnic uses 0x02 as the device address. However the documentation do not put any constraints to this value.
Returns the version of the sensor.
Returns the name of the manufacturer, e.g. "LEGO".
Reads the value of the variable stored at the address.
Reads the value of the variable stored at the two consecutive bytes at the address.
This exception is thrown when there is no connection to the NXT brick.
Exception thrown when there is an error in the communication to the NXT brick.
The NxtCommand that resulted in the exception.
The NxtErrorMessage that was returned from the NXT brick.
Indicates if the sensor should supply its own light.
The intensity of the measured light.
This event is fired whenever the measured light intensity passes above the threshold-intensity.
This event is fired whenever the measured light intensity passes below the threshold-intensity.
Polls the sensor, and fires the NXT-G like events if appropriate.
Delegate used for the NXT-G like events implemented in the motor.

Class representing a port with no sensor attached.

Abstract class representing a Passive Sensor.

remarks.para: According to the LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT Hardware Developer Kit p. 7, sensors is divided into three types: active sensors (e.g. Robotics Invention Systems sensors), passive sensors (e.g. the NXT touch, light, and sound sensors), and digital sensors (e.g. the NXT ultrasonic sensor and the HiTechnic compass sensor). The three abstract classes NxtActiveSensor, NxtPassiveSensor, and NxtDigitalSensor reflect this.

summary.para: The data from the last poll of the sensor.
Delegate used when a motor or sensor is polled.
Abstract class used as superclass for the NxtMotor and NxtSensor classes.

remarks.para: This class has been modified from using System.Timers.Timer (in versions 1.0 and 1.1) to using System.Threading.Timer in order to be able to function with the compact framework (i.e. to run on a PDA). A special thanks to Giorgio T. for his suggestion.

summary.para: The NXT brick that the sensor/motor is attached to.
The NXT brick that the sensor/motor is attached to.
Indicates if the sensor, or motor, is auto-polled or not.

value.para: A positive value means that the sensor is auto-pooled, and with the indicated interval i milliseconds.
Zero, or a negative value, means that the sensor is not auto-polled.

summary.para: This event is triggered by the auto-poll timer.
This event is fired when the sensor, or motor, is polled.
Delegate used for the NXT-G like events implemented in the various sensors.

remarks.para: Used as base class for the specific sensor classes.

summary.para: The port the sensor is attached to.
The port on the NXT brick that the sensor is attached to.
Indicating if the sensor should return results as dB or as dBA (adjusted for the human ear).
This event is fired whenever the measured sound intensity passes above the threshold-level.
This event is fired whenever the measured sound intensity passes below the threshold-level.
Polls the sensor, and fires the NXT-G like events if appropriate.
Indicating if the sensor-button is pressed or not.
This event is fired when the touch sensor is pressed.
This event is fired when the touch sensor is released.
Polls the sensor, and fires the NXT-G like events if appropriate.

remarks.para: The I2C protocol for the Ultrasonic sensor is specified in the document:

Lego Mindstorms NXT,
Hardware Developer Kit,
Appendix 7: LEGO MINDSTORMS NXT Ultrasonic Sensor I2C communication protocol

which can be downloaded at:
http://mindstorms.lego.com/overview/NXTreme.aspx

A special thanks goes to Dick Swan and Templar for their invaluable explanations in:
http://forums.nxtasy.org/index.php?showtopic=141
The resulting code stated out being part of the NxtUltrasonicSensor class but has since been moved to the NxtDigitalSensor class.

summary.para: Returns the measured distance in cm.
Returns the "factory zero" of the sensor.
Returns the "factory scale factor" of the sensor.
Returns the factory scale divisor of the sensor.
Returns the measurement units if the sensor, e.g. "10E-2m".

remarks.para: See the remark for ReadActualScaleDivisor().

summary.para: This event is fired if the sensor detects an object within the threshold distance.
This event is fired if the sensor does not detect an object within the threshold distance.
The data from the previous poll of the sensor.
Polls the sensor, and fires the NXT-G like events if appropriate.
